lines.text: Enter DUKE ORSINO, VIOLA, CURIO, and others

lines.speaker: duke orsino
lines.text: Give me some music. Now, good morrow, friends. Now, good Cesario, but that piece of song, That old and antique song we heard last night: Methought it did relieve my passion much, More than light airs and recollected terms Of these most brisk and giddy-paced times: Come, but one verse.

lines.speaker: curio
lines.text: He is not here, so please your lordship that should sing it.

lines.speaker: duke orsino
lines.text: Who was it?

lines.speaker: curio
lines.text: Feste, the jester, my lord; a fool that the lady Olivia's father took much delight in. He is about the house.

lines.speaker: duke orsino
lines.text: Seek him out, and play the tune the while. Come hither, boy: if ever thou shalt love, In the sweet pangs of it remember me; For such as I am all true lovers are, Unstaid and skittish in all motions else, Save in the constant image of the creature That is beloved. How dost thou like this tune?
Exit CURIO. Music plays

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: It gives a very echo to the seat Where Love is throned.

lines.speaker: duke orsino
lines.text: Thou dost speak masterly: My life upon't, young though thou art, thine eye Hath stay'd upon some favour that it loves: Hath it not, boy?

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: A little, by your favour.

lines.speaker: duke orsino
lines.text: What kind of woman is't?

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: Of your complexion.

lines.speaker: duke orsino
lines.text: She is not worth thee, then. What years, i' faith?

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: About your years, my lord.

lines.speaker: duke orsino
lines.text: Too old by heaven: let still the woman take An elder than herself: so wears she to him, So sways she level in her husband's heart: For, boy, however we do praise ourselves, Our fancies are more giddy and unfirm, More longing, wavering, sooner lost and worn, Than women's are.

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: I think it well, my lord.

lines.speaker: duke orsino
lines.text: Then let thy love be younger than thyself, Or thy affection cannot hold the bent; For women are as roses, whose fair flower Being once display'd, doth fall that very hour.

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: And so they are: alas, that they are so; To die, even when they to perfection grow!
Re-enter CURIO and Clown

lines.speaker: duke orsino
lines.text: O, fellow, come, the song we had last night. Mark it, Cesario, it is old and plain; The spinsters and the knitters in the sun And the free maids that weave their thread with bones Do use to chant it: it is silly sooth, And dallies with the innocence of love, Like the old age.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Are you ready, sir?

lines.speaker: duke orsino
lines.text: Ay; prithee, sing. SONG.
Music

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Come away, come away, death, And in sad cypress let me be laid; Fly away, fly away breath; I am slain by a fair cruel maid. My shroud of white, stuck all with yew, O, prepare it! My part of death, no one so true Did share it. Not a flower, not a flower sweet On my black coffin let there be strown; Not a friend, not a friend greet My poor corpse, where my bones shall be thrown: A thousand thousand sighs to save, Lay me, O, where Sad true lover never find my grave, To weep there!

lines.speaker: duke orsino
lines.text: There's for thy pains.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: No pains, sir: I take pleasure in singing, sir.

lines.speaker: duke orsino
lines.text: I'll pay thy pleasure then.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Truly, sir, and pleasure will be paid, one time or another.

lines.speaker: duke orsino
lines.text: Give me now leave to leave thee.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Now, the melancholy god protect thee; and the tailor make thy doublet of changeable taffeta, for thy mind is a very opal. I would have men of such constancy put to sea, that their business might be every thing and their intent every where; for that's it that always makes a good voyage of nothing. Farewell.
Exit

lines.speaker: duke orsino
lines.text: Let all the rest give place. Once more, Cesario, Get thee to yond same sovereign cruelty: Tell her, my love, more noble than the world, Prizes not quantity of dirty lands; The parts that fortune hath bestow'd upon her, Tell her, I hold as giddily as fortune; But 'tis that miracle and queen of gems That nature pranks her in attracts my soul.
CURIO and Attendants retire

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: But if she cannot love you, sir?

lines.speaker: duke orsino
lines.text: I cannot be so answer'd.

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: Sooth, but you must. Say that some lady, as perhaps there is, Hath for your love a great a pang of heart As you have for Olivia: you cannot love her; You tell her so; must she not then be answer'd?

lines.speaker: duke orsino
lines.text: There is no woman's sides Can bide the beating of so strong a passion As love doth give my heart; no woman's heart So big, to hold so much; they lack retention Alas, their love may be call'd appetite, No motion of the liver, but the palate, That suffer surfeit, cloyment and revolt; But mine is all as hungry as the sea, And can digest as much: make no compare Between that love a woman can bear me And that I owe Olivia.

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: Ay, but I know--

lines.speaker: duke orsino
lines.text: What dost thou know?

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: Too well what love women to men may owe: In faith, they are as true of heart as we. My father had a daughter loved a man, As it might be, perhaps, were I a woman, I should your lordship.

lines.speaker: duke orsino
lines.text: And what's her history?

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: A blank, my lord. She never told her love, But let concealment, like a worm i' the bud, Feed on her damask cheek: she pined in thought, And with a green and yellow melancholy She sat like patience on a monument, Smiling at grief. Was not this love indeed? We men may say more, swear more: but indeed Our shows are more than will; for still we prove Much in our vows, but little in our love.

lines.speaker: duke orsino
lines.text: But died thy sister of her love, my boy?

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: I am all the daughters of my father's house, And all the brothers too: and yet I know not. Sir, shall I to this lady?

lines.speaker: duke orsino
lines.text: Ay, that's the theme. To her in haste; give her this jewel; say, My love can give no place, bide no denay.
Exeunt
